OverviewThis is a fully functioning RPG with 3 games: you can play as Baby Jesus, Adult Jesus, or Jesus after the rising. I've only tried playing as Baby Jesus so far and have found the experience surprisingly fun - way more than I expected it to be! The game is very easy to understand and grasp - you'll get the hang of how things work after some trial and error, even if RPGs aren't your thing.

Playing the Baby Jesus game    You get to control Mary and Joseph first, and lead them through to the birth of Christ. After Jesus is born, the game then switches you over to the 3 wise men, which you control. You must lead them from their kingdom through the desert and other locations until you reach Christ in Bethlehem. After visiting Christ and giving him their gifts, you then switch back to playing Mary, Joseph and now Baby Jesus as well.

As the 3 wise men, en route to visiting Baby Jesus, you will fight random enemies - both human and non-human - and get to visit nomad camps where you can recharge (miracle pools" restore all HP and other aspects)

reviewText:
Im going to review this game from my gamer point of view.

Controlls: Arrow keys to move, Z/Space is the action key and X/Escape to open the menu.

The music isen't good, I am not joking when I say I got a headache from it. The music does get alittle better later on but it's just a few tracks in the 3 RPGs put together. There is no option in the game to turn down the music or sound effects not even a mute within the game.

The animation is crudly simplistic, not like a retro looking game (UNDERTALE example), but more like the animator did not have the time or skill to make it better since it looks like a childs parody on a sitcom of the artstyle of (South Park).
It is easy to see who Jesus is. The others are mostly too blad to be able to seperate from each other. In the cut-like-sceens you can see the difference between Judas, Jesus and Mary. The 3 wise kings are all small 1st graders view of how a wizard looks. They do not have facial feathers just the hair, black skin and different colors on the clothings. All their countrymen/subjects have the same layout just with all green clothing.
Most of the NPCs are just copy pasted on their apperence, there are afew kinda funny NPCs in hell. The Apostles of Jesus look mostly the same appart from the 3 you get in the party. You need to cure people of illnesses, and some of them needs the word of Jesus to deside something.
Enemys have mostly just a few bodys to share. There are blue robbers with black robes, demons in suits and sunglasses in different colors, the demon's skins not the suits their black. Floating crystal like heads with eyes and a mouth, the boss Ahura Mazda has this skin first but a slight color change is the thing that differs this God's apperence from the random enemys that come after him. Tammuz is looking like this too. Do not fight him he is a sponge with ok dmg that will take a long time to kill and he does not give as much exp or cash as the other enemys. A king you meet in the wise king's quest becomes a random encounter in the 3rd one. Soldiers, Demons and Turists will have their body on the map like (Pokemon Trainers) but short sighted so that you can fight them or not. There is also a Belzebub demon fly skin with 2 minions that has just a different color then the boss. Only a few of the bosses are worth nothing cause they have their own skins that are no reused. Satan, Pandemonium and a few others are on this list.

The Combat is just like in (Final Fantasy 1). Turnbased where you need to use your entire teams abilitys and then they will all do their thing. You can not see your party in other ways then a hp bar, menu, but not the body of them only the enemys in a bland background. The attack effects are almost not even there and really bland. You have 5 different meters in the Combat that you can use. HP, MP, MP, AP and TP. Health Points: no need to explain what this is. Miracle Points: The same as mana but it only works with Jesus's miracle moves, later some others in your party will get miracle skills to. Magic Points: Only the 3 wise kings can use magic and you get magic buy taking on magical weapons. Angel Points: Virgin Mary is the only one that can use this, you summon angels that can do 1 thing each, just like a skill, Talent Points: Some humans can use this, it is just like magic but it replaces the (Angel Point bar) in later parts of the trilogy. You have consumables like Fish, Water, Bread and so on. They can restore your point bars, read to check what they do but they do not give the % or number of how much they do. The EGG is the same as a (Final Fantasy - Phoenix Down). Most have 2 weapon slots. Jesus will never learn to hold a weapon or attack. It isen't more then 10 levels and they will make you overpowered each level since you get like 100 or more hp from just going to level 2. In Rise of Jesus the cap level is more then 10. There are some healing springs in the world but no other ways in the start to survive then using consumables. Refrain is nothing more then a Defend move,

The Story follows (The new Testament), atleast the most famous parts with alot of fantasy in there. Mech, tower of Bable and other things like this.

In no way is this a good game, but if you wanna test this out for yourself then do it. It is free after all. Good Luck and Have fun :)

reviewText:
This is one of the greatest games of our generation. Based on the popular fanfiction known as 'The New Testament', the Jesus Christ RPG allows you to take control of the messiah himself in a very realistic fashion. The gameplay is like a combination of Baldur's Gate, Devil May Cry, and Phantasmagoria. It works so well together with the story as well. It really does feel as if every choice you make has weight and consequences.

Never before have I been so immersed in a game. The atmosphere and world are expertly-crafted to the degree of making games like Fallout and VTMB: Bloodlines seem as if they were designed by mere children. The story is dark, but beautifully-written. It revolves around the tragedy of a gifted man trying to make the world a better place, who is ultimately condemned by the very people he sought to protect.

I honestly could not tell if this game was made by people or by God himself. It has set new industry standards with its mind-blowing visuals, gritty & immersive atmosphere, innovative & challenging gameplay, and a rich story that puts Shakespearean literature to shame.

10/10

reviewText:
Let me say right off the bat that I'm not the most religious person out there... and that I've seen a lot of off the wall video game concepts... from things like the Binding of Issac to Conker's Bad Fur Day, from Shaq Fu to Grand Theft Auto, from NCIS to Lego Batman... like comic books, if you can imagine something, it can be done in the realm of games being created...

Which brings me... 'Jesus Christ RPG'...

Developed and Published by Wholeton Games, and released for Free on Steam just in time for Easter here in 2016... 'Jesus Christ RPG' is perhaps the most surreal concept I've ever seen...

In short... it's Pokemon mixed with elements The Bible... okay that's silly... more like Final Fantasy meets The Bible.

Yeah that is as surreal as it sounds... as you level up 'Our Savior' he learns how to do his miracles (turn water to wine, heal the sick, etc, etc).... and you battle 'demons' while finding your apostles... and also recruiting your part (consisting of  Simon Peter, Mary Magdalene and Judus who joins you no matter if you like it or not)

The game is done on a turn base system, much like many other RPGs, you input your commands when it's your turn, there is some thinking involved to realize how to use everyone's abilities.

Controls are simple, you use the keyboard.... the arrow keys to navigate, enter to select menu options, the ESC key to bring up your inventory, save, status screens... and space bar to interact with objects and people.

However it's the surreal nature of the game that makes it worth playing, there is an actual in-joke about the language (namely that they didn't speak English back in Biblical times), and Mary being apparently an overly common name.

Since the game is free is worth checking out.

reviewText: Although I was expecting an unintelligent mockery of Christianity, this game is whimsical and humorous like the old RPGs in the 90's, and it is well-researched. The developers clearly did their historical and theological homework, which provides for some interesting gameplay mechanics and story progression, such as a detour to the Tower of Babel or playing as the magi, who derive their magical powers from weapons named after their gods. The plot stays mostly true to the Biblical account of Jesus' life and ministry (as far as I played, which is approximately halfway through), and depicting Satan as a corporate hack/ pimp with a suit and sunglasses is brilliant. However, the game mechanics are nonetheless shallow, and the potential for this to be an epic game on the scale of Super Mario RPG or Final Fantasy V falls short for a number of probable reasons (i.e. scope, commitment, software, etc.), but talent certaintly isn't one of them. The Tower of Babel could have been a world of its own had the developers given it more depth, and I would have liked to have seen a little more interactivity on par with some of Square's SNES games. The game is worth checking out since it's free, but I advise caution because one of the bosses, a giant mech called S.A.T.A.N., is unbeatable, preventing the player from experiencing the rest of the game. As a Christian, I liked the game and can tolerate its flaws. I suspect that the game may have actually been developed by Christians due to the accuracy of some theological elements and subtle commentary. Regardless, Christian developers should at least take note of this game and try not to overthink it. In the least, it may get nonbelievers engaged in the basics of Christianity, especially at a time when Biblical illiteracy and hatred of the Bible are at an all time high.

reviewText: Although I was expecting an unintelligent mockery of Christianity, this game is whimsical and humorous like the old RPGs in the 90's, and it is well-researched. The developers clearly did their historical and theological homework, which provides for some interesting gameplay mechanics and story progression, such as a detour to the Tower of Babel or playing as the magi, who derive their magical powers from weapons named after their gods. The plot stays mostly true to the Biblical account of Jesus' life and ministry (as far as I played, which is approximately halfway through), and depicting Satan as a corporate hack/ pimp with a suit and sunglasses is brilliant. However, the game mechanics are nonetheless shallow, and the potential for this to be an epic game on the scale of Super Mario RPG or Final Fantasy V falls short for a number of probable reasons (i.e. scope, commitment, software, etc.), but talent certaintly isn't one of them. The Tower of Babel could have been a world of its own had the developers given it more depth, and I would have liked to have seen a little more interactivity on par with some of Square's SNES games. The game is worth checking out since it's free, but I advise caution because one of the bosses, a giant mech called S.A.T.A.N., is unbeatable, preventing the player from experiencing the rest of the game. As a Christian, I liked the game and can tolerate its flaws. I suspect that the game may have actually been developed by Christians due to the accuracy of some theological elements and subtle commentary. Regardless, Christian developers should at least take note of this game and try not to overthink it. In the least, it may get nonbelievers engaged in the basics of Christianity, especially at a time when Biblical illiteracy and hatred of the Bible are at an all time high.
